profileText: A Delegate from the Territory of Nevada; born in Circleville, Pickaway County, Ohio, February 22, 1819; attended the common schools, Kenyon College, Gambier, Ohio, and Oxford (Ohio) University; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1840; appointed United States associate justice for the district of Utah on June 4, 1858; moved to Carson City, Nev.; upon the formation of the Territory of Nevada was elected a Delegate to the Thirty-seventh Congress and served from December 2, 1861, to March 3, 1863; colonel of the One Hundred and Fourteenth Regiment, Ohio Volunteer Infantry, and served from April 27, 1862, until honorably discharged October 20, 1863, on tender of resignation; wounded at Vicksburg; returned to Nevada and settled in Eureka; engaged in the mining business until his death in Eureka, Nev., February 22, 1872; interment in Forest Cemetery, Circleville, Ohio.

researchRecord.name: In the George Hampton Crosman Papers, 1860, 6 letters.
researchRecord.description: Includes a copy of remarks delivered by Judge John Cradlebaugh on March 30, 1859 in response to a proclamation from the governor protesting against the presence of troops around Provo.

researchRecord.name: 1861, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter of resignation dated February 12, 1861 written by John Cradlebaugh. In the letter, John Cradlebaugh states that he will no longer serve as a judge in the territory of Utah.
